Hi,  QUESTION: What is the difference between Simple Harmonic Motion, (Complex) Harmonic Motion, Periodic Motion, Aperiodic Motion? Is Complex Harmonic Motion and Periodic Motion the same thing? I just try to search on it and find nowhere a clear answer on that.   My assumption:  Simple harmonic motion x(t) can be described as x(t)=Asin(ωt+φ). And a periodic motion (i assume that it's the same as harmonic motion) can be described as a sum of simple harmonic motions, where ω_k/ω_l for k,l∈Z+ is a rational number. And The motion is aperiodic, if this ratio two omegas is irrational. Am i right? :///

Great video as always. I know some people are complaining about the speed of these videos, but I actually think it's great to have such an option. For people who learn better through longwinded explanations, they can watch khan academy, and people who learn better through quick and snappy explanations can come here. The great thing about the internet and the technological age is that there has never been a more customizable learning experience. There's something for everyone. Oh and unlike crash course organic chemistry, which barely helped me at all in my first semester of ochem, this series actually will get you through calculus based-physics 1 and 2 in college. I love that you aren't afraid of alienating the fans by actually getting into the technical aspects, and believe that the experience and educational value of these videos has benefited profoundly for it. Keep it up!

The millenium bridge was one of the greatest cock-ups of engineering like, ever. That's a valid question.  With the circular motion you will have an angular velocity (usually lowercase omega but I'll use w).  If you do the thing and tilt it like she did to where it looks like something going back and forth it will be relatable to the mass-spring system by w=(k/m)^1/2.  This is helpful because the solutions for each of them will be basically the same even though they are seemingly unrelated.

A majority of those learning mechanics havent touched differential equations in the American system. When I was taking a course over E&M my freshman year, we had the solution to differential equations for time-dependent current/charge/etc. in circuits given to us, because, well, no one could solve them yet. It's usually a sophomore-level class for most universities, whereas mechanics and E&M are freshman intro classes.

Yes. But knowing how to solve the 2nd order ODE or the wave equation, the diffusion equation etc. (in short having taken one or two introductory classes in DEs) does demystify all the solutions that you get. If I watched this video without already knowing all the material it would have seemed like black magic to me.

"Particles" are objects with narrow wavefunctions in space. All continuous wavefunctions can be described as "waves" (i.e. their Fourier transform). Thus the "wave-like" character becomes prominent in all objects with spatially broad wavefunctions.  I don't expect that they'll cover too much QM in this series. However they should cover some classical electrodynamics which probably even more important.
You can always pause the video, or lower its speed. It's certainly fast paced, but the format allows you to learn at your own pace

Yeah, except that diameter is absolutely useless in math. There are infinite shapes with a uniform diameter, but only one, the circle, with uniform radius. If you want to talk about how things move in time, you're talking about eigenfunctions of the derivative, which give you exponentials, which give you trig functions, which are expressed in terms of the radius of the circle and the circle constant, τ. From harmonic motion, to periodicity of trig functions, to the complex exponential, to Fourier transforms, τ shows up as the fundamental circle constant. Only when a factor of a half is involved does π appear by itself.

The acceleration of an object traveling in simple harmonic motion is proportional to the product of the distance from equilibrium and -ω². It could also be given by the differential equation, x'''(t) = -ω² x(t)
It's actually very elementary physics

I am not very familiar with this particular case of bridge failure, but Dr. Shini says it was due to the footsteps which tells me that the bridge designers didn't account for a large enough eccentricity of the loading. The friction and resistance you are referring to is called dampening, and when there is dampening in a system it is no longer considered as 'simple harmonic motion', it is called 'free damped motion'. The differential equation in this case becomes x''(t)+cx'(t)+w^2x(t)=0. So I hope that answers the first part of the question. As for why the bridge keeps moving it's because the motion started to resonate. To describe the motion of the bridge when people were walking on it we can use the 'undamped forced motion' equation, which is x''(t)+w^2x(t)=Fsin(at) where a does not equal w. The right side of the equation represents the force applied and its periodic nature, the left side is just the equation from before ignoring dampening as you already mentioned it doesn't seem like its doing a lot. I know it sounds like a lot so far, but bare with me. The solution to this equation assuming no initial displacement or velocity before the force was applied is x(t)=(F/2w^2)sin(wt)-(F/2w)tcos(wt). Notice the t term in front of the cosine term, as time goes this term will get larger and as this term gets larger and larger the amplitude of the displacement will get larger and larger. As people were leaning in to the sway they were also increasing the F term which would only further increase the displacement. If that was all too complicated in simple terms, when structures start to resonate they are really hard to stop and impossible if the loading that lead to the resonance is sustained.

Music has set beats, or meter, and variety can be achieved by subdividing beats, or holding for multiple beats.  The point is that the beat is recognizable as a unifying element that's consistent throughout even with the different variations.  Architecture often uses a grid to establish a unit of measurement that's used throughout the building, even though it may be divided in half, or in thirds, etc.  The unit of measurement, or grid spacing, creates a sense of unity in the building, meaning all the elements seem related to each other.

The Tacoma Narrows bridge failed due to aeroelastic flutter, not resonance (at least, according to the mechanics professor from my degree). Aeroelastic flutter is a positive feedback effect: as the bridge oscillated and tilted, the wind striking it at an angle exerted a force. As the force cause the oscillation amplitude to increase, the bridge deformed to a steeper angle, exerting more force and deforming it to an even steeper angle until... well, y'know
Minute Physics has a great video explaining how the Tacoma Narrows case is not due to resonance.

If by lactose intolerant, you mean reduced tolerance and developed intolerance at an older age, then yes.   Cats are the prime example. They can drink milk when they are kittens and it is nutritious for them to do so. But, as they age into adult cats, their lactose digestion ability is reduced. This is true for all cats and milk will be harder for them to digest and may cause stomach problems. And for some cats, they may become completely lactose intolerant once they are adults.
+Silverizael they said non mammal

Darkstar22 Whoops, I missed that part. :P  Um...I would largely say no then, since lactation from mammary glands is only a thing mammals do. Non-mammals wouldn't have any involvement with it, so they would have no need to be lactose-intolerant.  It's quite possible that one could induce such intolerance over generations with a non-mammal, but i'm not sure if they would have such intolerance inherently. If they do, the intolerance would have to do with lactose from some other nutrition source other than milk.   And I can't think of any other substance that involves hydrolyzed dissacharides of galactose and glucose, so i'm going to go ahead and presume it doesn't exist.   So, in short, no.
+Silverizael isn't lactose intolerance the inability to digest it if so then I guess they are all intolerant or did I misread.

Darkstar22 I worded that poorly. Sorry. Yes, they are probably all lactose-intolerant just by the fact that they can't digest lactase, since they would have no need to, as lactation and milk production has no meaning outside of mammals.   I came at it and worded it from the wrong angle, so it got kinda confusing.
Depends what you mean by non mammals. In microbiology the ability or inability to ferment lactose is a major classification used to identify organisms, and your answer would be yes.

By non-mammal, I mean macrobiology things. And I know that since non-mammals don't lactate, they wouldn't have an reason to tolerate lactose, but I saw this one video of a fish drinking milk, so I got real curious.

Hideous Gourd it depends on the specific microflora of the creature. You can thank microorganisms for most of digestion within us and almost all animals. I'm sure you've heard the fact that there are 10x more bacterial cells that make up us then human cells... And they're crucial. And what you defecate after you eat it isn't just "digested food" its mostly dead bacteria.  So if for whatever reason the fish lived in an environment that was rich in free lactose.. maybe it follows pregnant mammals? Then almost certainly lactobacillus or whomever would be present and could colonize their gut.  What we can or cannot digest mostly comes down to that. That's why fecal transplants are becoming the norm for serious digestive issues.   And why the cat cannot digest lactose after they stop...because more than likely the bacteria within their digestive system died out when they stopped.

Dr. Get Jammed That is very educational, but sadly, I lack the resources to identify the bacterial contents of various non-mammals' digestive systems. So the question still remains: do the bacteria allowing for the digestion of lactose exist in non-mammals?
